reviewText:
1.1/10 - Can't say we weren't warned! As Advertised.

I don't know what I was thinking when I paid full price for this game; it's bad. Have you ever sat in class and put dots on the page until your hand went numb? That's this game in a nutshell. It's like paying $1 to get a quick 100% achievement in the books. Completion of the game takes 5-30 minutes!

The game starts out by you simply clicking dots on the page, those dots explode and make new dots. You then click those new dots to make more dots. Here's where it gets interesting... Those new dots... they have to be clicked again to make more dots! It's amazing.

Itâ€™s worth nothing. Don't buy this. You shouldn't even be reading this review!

reviewText:
tl;dr: Game's literally pointless with god awful hit detection. For details, continue reading:

'Pointless' is a game all about clicking dots, and no, it's just not that simple. Not because it isn't simple, but because it isn't programmed to be simple. Not because it's clearly intentional. But because the programming just basically sucks. And you know it does when the first thing you're greeted with is a mock Gameboy screen meant to bring up nostalgia of a two-bit variety, only making the game look cheap and completely unoriginal, not to mention make you want to pull out that old brick of a portable handheld instead of play this. On top of that you have a repetitive score and random sound effects that mirror that system's capabilities, yet quickly grate on your nerves the more time you spend listening to them. Honestly, some of the cheap knock-off handheld companies back in the day had higher standards, though the Nintendo today may be willing to slap it up on their DS/3DS e-store.

Of course the huge problem about this title becomes immediately apparent with the first click of the mouse once the actual game" starts
date: and that is the hit detection is pure garbage. No
recommended: I wasn't just sitting here clicking tiny dots on a filthy laptop screen
hoursPlayed: though I admit it did happen more times than I'd like to admit to
voteText: but I found myself clicking upwards of twenty times rapid fire to get one single dot
helpfulPercent: only to watch it vanish and be forced to move on to the next in hopes of actually gaining that one point. In just ten seconds I conceded it'd just be easier to sit around waiting for the L power-up to show so I could have a little fun with it without the use of an auto-clicker hotkey script running in the background in a feeble attempt to rack up achievements to my Steam account.\n\nOn top of that
votesHelpful: 'Pointless' has no penalty system in place
votesTotal: so sitting around in no way hinders your progress. You're best bet is to just click and use one of five weapons
votesFunny: only three of which seem to have any real use. Pulse places three pulsating obstacles on the screen at points of your choice and
column16: will spread the dots and rack up thousands in one go. Bomb is nice if you have a number of clustered dots on screen as well. But then you have laser
column18: allowing you to hold the left mouse button down and automatically click. This one is best done by making small circular motions to rack up a decent amount of dots. These three work very well together if done right as well
column19: but long (black rectangle that crushes dots) has minimal benefit. There's also chain
column20: but I genuinely have no idea what it does
column21: if anything at all.\n\nThere are a few options
column24: as the title itself. There's music and sound effect volume controls
column25: as well as an option to change the background "color palette"
column26: but only after you destroy so many dots to unlock the other two distinctly bland colors of peach and tomato red. Yes
column27: that's all the cosmetic changes the development team has allowed. God forbid you get a third color scheme to unlock or new "game girl" handheld border because  us clicking pointlesly at pointless dots wouldn't possibly know what to do with that much power at our disposal other than watch the credits and add our pointless total to a pointless global score to show the world how collectively pathetic we as Steam users are in this day and age.\n\nThankfully for achievement hunters
column28: these are simple to rack up with some help. If you have an auto-clicker program or a script that runs in Hotkey
column29: something I wound up abusing by the six thousand dot mark and realized how little I could be bothered to try to click the many fleas infesting the digital handheld device that wouldn't die even when I properly clicked on them in the first damn place. You can scoff at the idea but
column31: it's almost necessary to do this since you have to have the game the active window at all times in order to get any weapons or new dots to appear on the screen.\n\n'Flea Extermination Simulator 2016' is
column33: a thing that exists. Is it a game? Not necessarily. Remember the old 'Game & Watch' style of handheld games? Well just picture a bunch of fleas somehow got into one of those
column34: and it's up to you to exterminate them all before they take over your house. This is 'Pointless'
column35: both in title and execution. The only goal this title serves is to add another cheap and quick one hundred percent complete title to the list of Steam games with achievements. Sadly
column36: without caving and using an auto-clicker
column37: you'll find it quite a tendious
column38: fairly broken experience that will leave you questioning where you went wrong in life that you're playing something worse than the recently released failure that is 'Bonsai'. Hopefully the developer becomes kind enough to throw some bonus colors or backgrounds into the mix
column39: maybe an actual game or mini-game to breathe life into this waste of a dollar but
column41: 'Pointless' is an absolutely "pointless" experience for anyone who's game completion percentage score and achievement count doesn't mean the world to them."

reviewText:
I finished everything this game has to offer in 40 minutes. And that was only because of the 100.000 dots achievement.
Mentally I was done after 5-10 minutes.
You click dots and that's the core of the game. Is it worth it over a pack of cookies? You decide.
I honestly went to the store before this and my cookies weren't as expensive as this game on sale.
There's better clicking games like cookie clicker and clicker heroes that are free.
In my opinion this game should be free aswell. If you're struggling for money, don't buy this game.
If you want easy achievements and steam cards, go ahead and buy it on sale.

column28: open the credits of the game and switch between a bunch of pointless color palettes. There are no options to change game resolution

So let me tell you exactly how my pointless gameplay experience was instead.\n\nI downloaded Pointless late at night and decided to play it to see if it would be worth it. That's easily the most pointless decision I have ever made. The game starts off alright

column41: and I got more and more interested in the game. After about five minutes

column47: 000 points. I was all broken down. It was utterly pointless. Yet
column48: I kept playing for some pointless reason
column49: and after some unknown amount of time

column51: the most pointless card I've ever gotten
column52:
I thought, figuring I could probably sell it on the Community Market, because I don't want to keep this pointless card in my inventory.

After 20 minutes, I started contemplating the meaning of life and the universe, and wondered why I had installed this pointless game in the first place. I would have been better off just leaving it in my library for some pointless reason than to set aside a few pointless megabytes for this game. Either way, I was going to reach that pointless 100,000 achievement at some point, so I kept playing, pointlessly.

40 minutes in, and the point counter was approaching 90,000. Finally, I thought, an end to this pointless game! As I reached 100,000 and got the last pointless achievement, I didn't hesitate to quit the game. Finally, I'm released from the pointless captivity of this pointless game! It was the greatest relief ever. I have officially *survived* Pointless. I should be proud of myself, but I'm not sure what the point of that would be.

To sum it up, this game is pointless. It does make a good point of killing your mouse, and thanks to this game, I now know what lurks within Room 101 from George Orwell's 1984". The torture chamber is literally playing "Pointless" to 1
column54: 000 points. No wonder why everyone was so desperate to avoid the pointless room. This game is pointless. There's no point in playing it. Overall rating: 1/10. Would not point my eyes at again."

reviewText: My first thought upon launching this game was 'wow, that looks cool!  The game is designed to look like a gameboy screen
date: complete with a matching backdrop.  It's a very nice looking game in that regard
recommended: but there didn't turn out to be a lot more to it than that
hoursPlayed: sadly.\n\nThe game itself involves clicking dots
voteText: pixels on the screen of the aforementioned gameboy (styled 'gamegal').  The dots disappear quite quickly
helpfulPercent: but clicking them spawns more dots.  The idea is to keep going without running out of dots.  Power-ups appear at regular intervals
votesHelpful: all of which help you by creating lots more dots in different ways.  There are two problems with this; firstly
votesTotal: it is very easy to keep going pretty much indefinitely
votesFunny: because the power-ups spawn just often enough to always save you when you are low on dots.  You'd have to be very unlucky to actually run out.  Secondly
commentsCount: there is no endpoint in sight
column16: save for the steam achievements and unlockable palette swaps.  However
column17: I have only played the game once.  The palettes were all unlocked within a few minutes
column18: and half an hour of relentless and eventually painful clicking
column19: I had all of the achievements too.  I quit the game after hitting 100
column21: because my hand hurt and there was seemingly nothing more to aim for anyway.\n\nEven as cheap as it is
column22: I can't recommend this one.  I can put it in my 'completed' pile after a single play.  There is no replay value
column24: no difficulty curve and it might give you RSI.  Should probably be free."

reviewText:
What is the point of this game? Who thought that this game would be a good idea? Why does this game even exist?

This is exactly what you're probably thinking about right now if even a shred of sanity exists in your mind. All that this game entails of is clicking an endless horde of pixels that explode in disappointing fashions. As the title suggests this game is 'Pointless' in every sense of the word and if I hadn't been given a 90% off Coupon this review would have never been created.

So please... if you somehow enjoy clicking and only clicking you will be glad to know that this title is right up your alley. If you enjoy things beyond clicking thousands of times then you should shuffle on from this page as quickly as possible as not to waste precious moments of our so very short lives.

reviewText: The name of the game sums it up pretty well. It's indie, because any lazy developer knowing the basics of working with Unity can probably has this together within a week. It's not retro, it's just a cheap looking game in Unity. A clicker? Just be carefull, the game can crash, being built in Unity. Otherwise a single playthrough can net you all achievements. It's pointless to waste 99 cents on it though. I probably got it as part of some bundle. And the playtime because of trading card idling.

reviewText:
I really shouldn't recommend but can't not recommend because the game is competently built and well polished.

Gameplay is as follows:
Left click to explode dots into smaller dots
Collect power up to make an even bigger mess of dots

You can't die or fail hence the title aside from the fact that you're trying to clear the screen of points.

$1 isn't asking too much if you're into developing games yourself and want a resource for an educational example.
For most gamers, however, I'm sure you have a massive backlog and this is a real time-waster so I would just keep my eyes peeled for bundles featuring the game as you'll be hard pressed to ever find yourself spending more than ten minutes in this game.
